text: [crowd whooping]
HU!
HU!
U!
[whooping resumes]
The home by the sea!
[grunting]
HU.
[cheers and applause]

- What do fraternities do
at white colleges?

- They drink, party,
and they drink again.
[cheers and applause continue]

all:
♪ Facing the rising sun ♪
♪ Of our new day begun ♪

♪ Let us march on ♪
- Let's march on.

all:
♪ Till victory ♪
♪ Is won ♪

- Thank you all for coming,
and see you all next year.
[applause]
- How did you know the song?
- Beyoncé, Coachella.

It's pretty emotional,
isn't it?

- Did you know there was
a Black national anthem?

- Yeah, but I thought it was
"[bleep] Tha Police."

What's up with those
extra gift bags?
Hold on, excuse me.
Uh, 'Mira. Amira.

Ha ha,
that was dope, right?

I'm getting really good vibes
from Hampton.

I think it's a good school, and
I think it'd be great for you.

- Well, I'm glad you liked it.
It was definitely something.

But I think I'd rather go
to Georgetown.
- Wait a minute.

Was we at two different
presentations right there?

'Cause what I saw on that stage
is more than just something.

And you still choose
Georgetown?

- Yeah, I just--I think
I'd do better there.
- Amira, come here.
You're like a kid genius.

I'm still in awe
that you come from me.
Now, Shahzad, I know he mines.

But you gonna shine
wherever you go.

So, baby girl,
what's the real problem?
- I just--

I feel like I'm not gonna
fit in at Hampton.
What if I'm not Black enough?

- You Black enough to fill
any space you choose,

so don't you ever
question yourself.

- I'm sorry, Dad, but my
decision is not gonna change.

I just--I want to go
to Georgetown

where I'll feel
more comfortable.

- Was you comfortable
being ignored

at that Georgetown
presentation?

- No.
No, of course, not.
- So you'll be more comfortable

being uncomfortable
around white people

than you would be
around Black people?
- Yes.
[hip-hop music]

- What's going on?
- It's Amira.

She don't think she
Black enough to go to Hampton,
so she's choosing Georgetown.
- What? Wait.

Amira, why are you calling
your Blackness
into question all of a sudden?
- Can you not be a white dad

in an HBCU hat
asking me that right now?
- Touché, right?
- As promised...
Can I borrow her for a second?
- Sure.
- I saw you back there.

It's a little
overwhelming, huh?
- You could tell?

- Girl, I didn't even know
there was

a Black national anthem
until my orientation day.

- Okay, thank you
for saying that.
- Look, I know it's a lot,

but it's not meant
to isolate you.
It's meant to reassure you.

- I was totally having
an identity crisis.

- I get it, but sometimes
what feels like a crisis

is actually the beginning
of an awakening.

And I promise I'm not trying
to get all T.D. Jakes on you.

I'm just saying it because
I've been in your shoes.
It took me a while,

but the thing I learned
the most at Hampton,

is that Blackness
is so many things.

There isn't one way
to be Black,

and you decide
what that means for you.

Well, you and Black Twitter.
[both chuckle]
